postsData.content:
What’s your top priority for growth this year: Expanding your market, improving products, or investing in AI and analytics?

According to key insights from asurvey of 12,000+ senior business leaders, midsize companies are focused on growth, simplification, and innovation..

Here’s a quick look at what’s driving their strategies:

Growth Priorities 
 43.3% of respondents see expanding distribution channels and partners as their top growth strategy.
 74.6% rank expanding distribution channels in their top 3 priorities.
 79.3% are focused on expanding their existing market presence.
 54.3% aim to scale their business operations.

Simplification Priorities ️
 23% of companies consider improving product/service development processes as their top simplification strategy.
 54.5% prioritize enhancing product development processes.
 51.8% emphasize increasing integration between enterprise systems.
 44.7% focus on improving cost control and managing spending.

Growth Challenges & Tech Priorities 
 39.1% cite weak procurement & supply chain processes as barriers
 34.9% struggle with lack of quality data & tools for decision-making.
 55.1% of growth-focused companies are investing in analytics and decision-making tools.
 51.7% are prioritizing business software systems and tools.

AI & Cybersecurity 
 80%+ see AI as a medium to high priority for transforming business processes.
 Expansion-minded companies are more likely to rank AI as a top priority.
 Cybersecurity threats are top of mind, especially for growth-focused and improvement-focused companies.

Midsize companies are doubling down on expanding distribution, improving product development, and investing in technology like AI and analytics to fuel their growth. At the same time, simplifying operations and managing risks, especially in procurement and cybersecurity, remain critical focus areas.

How are you prioritizing growth and simplification in your business strategy?

postsData.name:
Derrick Hodge
Derrick Hodge
postsData.content:
The Hilbert Space of Compute Scaling

While the industry obsesses over token/sec metrics, they're missing the eigenspace decomposition happening in front of us.

That 100x compute differential? It's a symmetry-breaking event. Your gradient tweaks won't save you.

The math is unforgiving: recursive reasoning requires exploring the full configuration space before wavefunction collapse. This isn't an engineering problem - it's fundamental quantum mechanics.

We're hitting the Shannon bound on naive inference. But recursive architectures are quantum tunneling through the complexity barrier, establishing new ground states in cognitive phase space. This is the real economic consequences, a bifurcation point.

The concerning part: The gap between organizations with access to this compute regime and those without grows as exp(t). Market dynamics undergo spontaneous symmetry breaking. Power concentrates along new attractors.

We witnessed this playout, when Deepseek's R1 -model, triggered a $2 Trillion drop in the market.

But the noise contains signal. Understanding these mathematical constraints lets us shape the attractor landscape rather than being shaped by it.

Stop optimizing surface metrics - start studying the quantum mechanics of recursive cognition.

comments.commentText: "The math is unforgiving: recursive reasoning requires exploring the full configuration space before wavefunction collapse. This isn't an engineering problem - it's fundamental quantum mechanics." Lucky for us, if we want to explore the Hilbert space it will have a cut off, and similar outcomes tend to cluster together, so I would argue that the computational penalty for searching the Hilbert space for the best or a good enough solution does not have to be exorbitant.

Bryan Clark Effective field theories and renormalization teach us something deeper, the compute penalty isn't about searching Hilbert space, it's about resolving the minimal causal degrees of freedom needed for coherent reasoning.

You're right about clustering, but it emerges from the symmetries of the representation space - that's why we hit 100x compute instead of exponential scaling.
This is great food for thought, I deal with this problem on a daily basis. Thanks for your response.

I agree with your argument that AI and compute are undergoing a fundamental shift akin to a quantum phase transition, and companies that fail to adapt will be left behind. 

Instead of optimizing superficial benchmarks, organizations should focus on recursive cognition and its quantum-like properties, as this will define the next generation of intelligence and economic power
Anthony L. That last part.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible insights! This shift in understanding compute dynamics is crucial for seizing competitive advantages in our evolving landscape.

postsData.name:
Ar. Swati Singh
Ar. Swati Singh
postsData.content:
hashtag
#justathought

Lately, I have been deeply reflecting on the state of architectural practice, particularly in smaller cities. There was a time when architects aspired to be part of visionary projects—projects that challenged them, pushed boundaries, and left a lasting impact. But today, I see a shift. More and more architects prefer to work independently, taking on small-scale projects just to stay free from long-term commitments. While independence is empowering, I fear that the spirit of collaboration, the drive to build something monumental, is gradually fading.

Every time I hire talented individuals, they learn for six months or a year, then leave to start their own practice, taking on projects for as little as ₹5,000 or ₹10,000. And they are content with it. But where does that leave the future of large-scale, high-value architecture? Where are the teams that dream of building cities, redefining skylines, and taking on projects that require vision, dedication, and long-term association?

If this trend continues, what happens when the current generation of architects leading multinational firms retires? Who will step up to take on those grand responsibilities? Architecture is not just about individual survival—it’s about collective progress. It’s about creating something that outlives us. But that requires commitment, patience, and the willingness to work as a team.

Being in a small town, I constantly strive to bring people together, to form a team that can take on ambitious projects. But finding architects who share this vision is becoming increasingly difficult. Despite these challenges, I remain committed to finding a way forward. I believe there is a solution, and I am determined to crack it.

To all architects out there—where do you see our profession in the coming years? Are we truly building the future, or are we just settling for convenience? It’s time we rethink our approach and bring back the spirit of collaboration, growth, and ambition in architecture.

Your calendar is having a nervous breakdown.

Your competitors aren't smarter—they just own 'no'.

They've tamed their priorities.
The rest? Just busy collectors.

Here's how to fight back:

️ The ONE Thing Question
↳ "What's the ONE thing that makes everything else easier or unnecessary?"
↳ This Gary Keller question kills complexity and reveals your true priority
↳ Write it down. It's your new filter for every "opportunity"

 The Buffett Elimination Method
↳ List your top 25 goals
↳ Circle only 5
↳ The other 20? Your "avoid at all costs list" - even if they're good ideas

 Power Block Defense
↳ Guard 90 minutes of your peak hours for your ONE thing
↳ Stanford found: Multi-taskers perform worse at every task
↳ No emails. No calls. No Tabs. Just pure execution.

⭐️ The 90-Second Filter
↳ Before every yes, ask: "Does this serve my ONE thing?"
↳ If it's not a clear yes, it's a Clear No.
↳ Even good opportunities steal from great ones

Your calendar called. It wants a divorce from chaos.
Start with ONE priority that changes everything.

postsData.name:
Nat Berman
Nat Berman
postsData.content:
You're looking at advertising all wrong. 

Most people see it as this:

→ A huge expense
→ Tons of data analysis
→ Not as legit as organic
→ Just an excuse to not work

This couldn't be further from the truth.

Yes, some people use advertising in this way.

And guess what? They are the ones who:

→ Burn through budget
→ Get the crappiest results
→ Wind up complaning about it

This is how you need to look at advertising:

→ Putting budget behind already excellent organic content.

Think about how you get clients on Linkedin:

→ Great content
→ Distribution of content
→ Distribution of content over and over
→ The viewer gets to know and trust you
→ Eventually you hit them with a sales post

You can do the exact same thing with advertising.

It doesn't have to be an ad that goes right to a sales page, landing page, VSL, newsletter subscription.

Why can't it just be extending the reach of an already awesome piece of content?

It CAN. And for a fraction of the cost.

Here's the quick and dirty:

→ Produce five pieces of amazing content
→ Content that educates and gives it all away
→ Put $5-$10 a day behind that content and run it
→ Save the audience who views that content the longest

So let's say you do a 5 minute video.

You then save the audience that watches say, 50% of the video.

You then create more content, but more sales driven.

Drive THAT content (i.e. retarget) to your original engaged audience from the first content :)

At that point they're already interested and potentially sold.

Get it?

If not, DM me "Advertise" and we can talk about it.

comments.commentText:
Want to know exactly WHAT to advertise?

Here's a manual way to do it. No tools, no APIs. 

Just a simple 24 hour test. 

Keep an excel sheet handy and simply copy and paste content that performs well.

What does "performs well" mean?

It means that content did what you wanted it to.

So perhaps it could have meant a ton of impressions, or it booked a lot of appointments.

Whatever your KPI is, keep a running list.

Simply let your post run for 24 hours and you'll know right away.

Chances are if that content does well organically, it will perform will in an ad.
Nat Berman a running list for all the needle moving KPIs.. I'm stealing this for my consulting clients

All really great advice Nat Berman. One area of caution though----$10 a day won't yield much result. To just be competitive now with any type of PPC ads you need a budget starting at $1500/month.

$5-10 a day won't win any of the bids and the ads won't get seen. You have to have a super savvy placement strategy as well. Ot is no longer a simple process (if you want real results). You have to consider:

- time ad runs
- limit you set for spend for each hour segments you choose
- retrieving formulas - no retrieving and you also likely won't get seen much.

I am a big fan of ads but the days of just dabbling with low funds sadly are gone. Anything less is literally wasting time and money.
David Rosenberg We're trapping the right views.

Nat Berman very lucky - great for you and I hope you continue to do so.

I promise though this is not the norm. Have been involved in literally 100s of digital ads across all platforms for years.

Cory Snyder
Cory Snyder
postsData.content:
Consulting/Fractional..... what is the difference and does the world know the difference?

I had this exact convo last week. I can't remember with who at this point, I suck I know.

My answer.....

- Talk about the work. What needs to be done, the how and so on
- Talk about the work, what needs to be done and the how BUT is the one to do it. Not just talk but action.

When I got laid off and started to officially do fractional work publicly I realized I am limited to my hours. I personally don't want to build a team either but I do need the help. Instead of 2 clients I could take on 5+ if I had access to people who could take the IC work off my hands.

That is where I went toand said "you should build this community of fractional executives all the way to IC side hustling individuals". I was that side hustle fractional guy. I didn't have a home. I didn't have a place I could offer up my services or ask for someone else to come in to do something I didnt want to do. Tyler loved the idea andsaid let's do it.

I reached out to 100 people. 50 in network and 50 out of network, only took an hour, and within 24 hours I had new connects and 40-50 convos.

The only issue..... These were all fractional executives like me. I needed to find those who were doing fractional work as a side hustle for a couple hours a week.

THAT is the hard part. How? Well through you all. Through those doing the fractional work full time. They have to know them....

If you know them, send them my way. We just launched the slack community. We have listings of fractional executives already live on PartnerStacks website. Let's help drive Fractional even further as an early option to companies instead of hiring.

It would probably save a ton of head and jobs honestly. Fractional will vet out the seriousness of the executive team and the buy in of the other teams. We get in, create progress and hit road block after road block.... bullet dodged for that person trying to work there.

On the other hand, we get progress, buy in and so on a job opens up and we leverage our network to fill it!

Some names in this community already,,,,,,,,and several others!

comments.commentText:
Cory Snyder I've viewed the distinction as

Consulting = external, project based (time bound) expertise on rent, with a specific package of services and focused on doing that same package of services many times over for multiple clients

Fractional = internal, role based, not necessarily time bound, and "right sized" to the role needs inside the company at its current stage

Consultants wouldn't normally get an email address and an onboarding flow; Fractional would.

Other distinctions like that.

Also reminds me ofand whatis working on
Sean Matthews great breakdown!

Cool initiative Cory - we split it into two buckets; the strategy/vision side, and the implementation side. The first is agile, reactive and usually takes precedence (because successful structure only ever follows a successful strategy) Implementation is an operational motion; takes time, many moving parts, etc. We started out doing both, but now concentrate on where the biggest difference usually lies; strategic planning and alignment

postsData.content:
In the world of AI, Data Science, and Machine Learning, 𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 alone won’t make you stand out.

Here are 8 powerful lessons DSML professional must know:

 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴
𝗕𝗲𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝗹𝗴𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗵𝗺𝘀, 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀 𝗼𝗻:

️ Data cleaning – Handle missing values, outliers, and inconsistencies.

️ Data visualization – Use Matplotlib, Seaborn, and Power BI to uncover insights.

️ Feature engineering – Create meaningful variables that boost model performance.

 𝗠𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 = 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗧𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝗝𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹𝘀

️ Supervised Learning: Regression & Classification for predictions.

️ Unsupervised Learning: Clustering & Dimensionality Reduction to find hidden patterns.

️ Reinforcement Learning: Learning through trial and error (used in AI & robotics).

 𝗔𝗰𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘆 𝗶𝘀 𝗮 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗠𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰
𝗔 𝗵𝗶𝗴𝗵 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘆 𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲. 𝗜𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗱, 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀 𝗼𝗻:

️ Precision & Recall – Essential for imbalanced datasets.

️ Cross-validation – Ensures your model performs well on unseen data.

️ Bias-Variance Tradeoff – Avoid overfitting and underfitting.

 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲 𝗖𝗮𝗿𝗹𝗼 𝗠𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗼𝗱𝘀 – 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗝𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗖𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗼𝘀

️ Monte Carlo simulations power finance, AI, and risk analysis by predicting uncertainty and optimization strategies.

 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀 & 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 – 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗯𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗠𝗟

️ Understand distributions, hypothesis testing, and Bayesian inference.

️ Learn to interpret p-values, confidence intervals, and correlations.

️ Without statistics, ML models are just black boxes.

 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗲𝘀 & 𝗘𝗻𝘀𝗲𝗺𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹𝘀 – 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗨𝗹𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗣𝗿𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀

️ Decision Trees – Simple but powerful interpretable models.

️ Random Forests – Multiple trees = better predictions.

️ Boosting (XGBoost, CatBoost, LightGBM) – The secret behind Kaggle-winning models.

 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝗵, 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰
𝗧𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗔𝗜, 𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱:

️ Backpropagation – How neural networks learn.

️ Activation Functions – ReLU, Sigmoid, Softmax, and their impact.

️ CNNs & RNNs – For image processing and sequential data.

 𝗞𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗪𝗶𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗨𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀

️ Work on real-world datasets – Kaggle, UCI, Google Dataset Search.

️ Contribute to open-source projects – Build your GitHub portfolio.

️ Join data science communities – Engage in discussions, hackathons, and networking.

Data Science & Machine Learning are about understanding data, statistics, and decision-making.

Learn the WHY, not just the HOW!

Patrick Spielmann
Patrick Spielmann
postsData.content:
Most cold emails fail, not because:

→ the product is bad.
→ the audience isn’t right.

But because, the email is all about you, not them.

Here’s the truth: Nobody cares about your offer.

They care about how it helps them.

How to Fix It:

1️⃣ Make It About Them
→ Address their pain points, not your features.
→ Show you understand their struggles.
→ Offer a clear, relevant solution.

2️⃣ Hook Them Instantly
→ Subject lines should spark curiosity.
→ First sentences should make them think, "This is for me."

3️⃣ Write Like a Human
→ Ditch the corporate jargon.
→ Keep it short, clear, and conversational.
→ Sound like someone they’d actually reply to.

4️⃣ Use Storytelling
→ People relate to stories, not pitches.
→ Share a quick example of how you solved a problem just like theirs.

5️⃣ Follow Up Relentlessly
→ The first email rarely lands the deal.
→ Be persistent, but add value with each touchpoint.

Don't send messages → start conversations.

Get that right, and you’ll turn emails into revenue.

comments.commentText: I agree

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Shifting the focus to the recipient is key. Personalization and storytelling can transform a cold email into a warm conversation! 🔑✨

Marketing has changed. Have you noticed?

Too many consultants, freelancers, and service providers are having a “Kodak Moment.”

(Not a fun, picture-perfect moment. I mean sticking with outdated strategies while the world moves on.)

Here’s what used to work:
 Posting on 3-5 platforms multiple times a day.
 Cold emails & calls.
 Complex funnels.
 Expensive ads.

That was my strategy for 15+ years. Then it stopped working.

I had to rebuild from scratch—and after nearly $1M in mistakes, I created a simple system that works today.

Here’s how it works:
1️⃣ Research with AI → I use AI to deeply understand my ideal clients and their “Value Journey.”
2️⃣ Help them → I provide high-value content—free—that helps them move forward.
3️⃣ Ask → I check if they liked what I shared. If they want more, I give them more.

Now, instead of chasing clients, they come to me. I spend more time doing what I love—and they get the results they want.

I put a guide together that walks through this process step by step. Want a copy? Let me know, and I’ll send it your way.

(See how this works? I’m giving you real value. You just have to ask. If you like it, you can ask for more. Easy.)

You're not alone if the thought of failing makes you freeze.

I’ve been there too:

• When I was a child, I was embarrassed by my attempts at hobbies.
• Then, I was terrified to start my own business.
• Even now, I get nervous before every new launch.

But EACH of those steps made me better.

Here’s what I believe now:

→ That "new thing" you’re hesitant to try?
It’s worth the discomfort.

→ That "failure" you’re afraid of?
It’s the first step towards your breakthrough.

→ That "inexperience"?
It’s just temporary.

Growth doesn’t come from staying comfortable.
It thrives in moments of vulnerability and uncertainty.

So be brave enough to suck at something new.

Take the leap and trust the process.

What’s something new you’ve started,
even if you weren’t perfect at it?

postsData.content:
I have 4 years of experience as a social media marketer and If I lost everything and had to restart my career…

Here’s EXACTLY what I’d do.

1️⃣ Start exactly where you are today.

Don’t overthink it.
→ Take free courses from HubSpot or Google and get certified.
→ Commit to learning and start applying it.

Even if you fail, learn from the process and try again.

2️⃣ Get access to all social media platforms.

Open accounts on all major platforms.
Follow relevant creators in your niche

3️⃣ Consume content and start recreating.

Check what all the creators are talking about, save it, and try recreating it with a touch of your expertise.

All you have to do is:
→ Provide value.
→ Solve problems.

If you don’t want to record yourself, simply write and start posting on.

And if you think you are too late,
Well, the creator economy is projected to be worth
$250 billion and will hit $1.4 trillion by 2034.

4️⃣ Build your network.

→ Start sending connection requests to relevant people in your niche on LinkedIn or explore relevant Facebook groups to network.
→ Send freebies or value-added resources to people, it helps build stronger relationships.

This will help you discover opportunities that you thought never existed.

5️⃣ Offer free work to gain experience.

→ Help small businesses or creators for free.
→ This builds your portfolio and gets you real-world experience.
→ Once you prove your skills, you can start charging for your services.

That’s all

You don’t need a perfect plan. You just need to start.
The journey won’t be easy, but it will be worth it.

All you need to do is:
 Stay hungry for growth.
 Keep networking.
 Explore every opportunity that comes your way.

PS: Repost this to help a beginner in your network.

postsData.content:
The Rise of AI Assistants: Transforming Work & Life 

AI assistants are reshaping industries with their unique capabilities. Here are 8 types of AI assistants, their roles, and advantages over others:

1️⃣ General AI Assistants (ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude)

 Role: Answer queries, generate content, and assist with brainstorming.
 Advantage: Versatile, adaptable across industries.

2️⃣ Personal Productivity Assistants (Microsoft Copilot, Notion AI)

 Role: Manage emails, schedule tasks, and automate workflows.
 Advantage: Enhances efficiency and time management.

3️⃣ Customer Support Bots (Drift, Intercom, Zendesk AI)

 Role: Handle FAQs, troubleshoot issues, and engage customers 24/7.
 Advantage: Reduces support costs, improves response time.

4️⃣ E-commerce & Sales Assistants (Shopify AI, Amazon Alexa)

 Role: Recommend products, assist in purchases, and automate sales queries.
 Advantage: Boosts conversion rates and personalizes shopping experiences.

5️⃣ Financial AI Assistants (Cleo, Plum, Olivia AI)

 Role: Budgeting, expense tracking, and investment suggestions.
 Advantage: Improves financial literacy and automates savings.

6️⃣ Healthcare AI Assistants (Woebot, Ada Health, Babylon)

 Role: Symptom checking, mental health support, and appointment scheduling.
 Advantage: Enhances accessibility and early diagnosis.

7️⃣ HR & Recruitment Assistants (HireVue, Paradox AI, HireEZ)

 Role: Resume screening, candidate shortlisting, and interview scheduling.
 Advantage: Reduces hiring time and biases.

8️⃣ Coding & Development Assistants (GitHub Copilot, Tabnine)

 Role: Code suggestions, debugging, and AI-powered auto-completion.
 Advantage: Accelerates development and reduces errors.

 AI assistants are enhancing productivity, saving time, and streamlining tasks across industries. Which AI assistant do you use the most?

postsData.content:
We onboarded 3 new clients last month while retaining 90% of our clients.

Here are my top 5 learnings:

 Goof-ups are a part of the process.
When you are growing, especially in a creative role such as Personal Branding for clients, there will be some goof-ups here & there.

The catch is to rectify them, be more careful next time & move on.
Don't linger!

 Rely heavily on the team and COMMUNICATE
We are a small team, making it both challenging and interesting.

I try to go on separate calls with everyone to discuss the strategy of clients, what are the challenges we are facing and how can we overcome them.

 Remove people who "drain" you

One thing I learned during my full-time role is "being prompt is the key". If a small task needs to be done, either a follow-up or sending a reply, or scheduling a call, the quicker you do the better.

If the whole team functions the same way, it just gets easier for everyone.

 You can take a weekend off, but your mind has multiple tabs open.

I am working on the "overthinking" part. But, well! I overthink client calls, what are we doing for them, and new leads that I would love to work with!

And that's okay!

 Finally, it's okay to stop comparing with others. Just compare it with your past self.

What would be your top learning this year?

postsData.content:
A coachee once walked into my office with a plan—a logical, structured roadmap for life after retirement. 

At 52, he was considering certification as an independent director, envisioning a quiet transition into advisory roles for engineering firms.

I paused him mid-sentence. “Retirement? At 52?
Should you be stepping off the field or preparing for a fresh innings?”

I shared the story of Sunil Gavaskar, who famously took fresh guard after reaching each century—a reminder to stay focused, recalibrate, and keep playing.

This struck a chord.
A few weeks later, he came back with a spark in his eyes.

He hadn’t just shifted his plans—he had reimagined his future.

While he didn’t say it out loud, his actions were clear: he was ready to play to his potential.

This idea of staying in the game, of leaning into possibility rather than stepping back, is central to’s Play to Potential – Lead a Full Life, Become the Best You.

Deepak, a stellar professional with roots in IIT Madras, IIM Ahmedabad, and London Business School, and a career spanning McKinsey, KPMG, and Egon Zehnder, chose to pivot in 2016.

He embraced executive coaching and launched the Play to Potential podcast—an exploration of life’s tipping points and purposeful transitions.

His book builds on these insights, offering readers a structured, relatable, and deeply human guide to rediscovering their potential.

What Makes This Book Stand Out?

1️⃣ Reframing Midlife:

The first section, The Long and Messy Midlife, speaks to those of us in our 40s and 50s wondering, “Is this all there is?” It challenges us to look beyond the “treadmill” of success and rediscover what truly matters.

2️⃣ Self-Reflection Made Practical:

In Getting in Touch With Ourselves, Deepak emphasizes 360-degree feedback and aligning with our values. He shares how he found his “sweet spot”—helping others unlock their potential.

3️⃣ A Roadmap to a Fuller Life:

The book’s highlight is the FLAVOUR framework:
F: Family context
L: What you love
A: Aspirations and choices
VO: Value and opportunities
U: Investing in yourself
R: Relationships

These aren’t abstract ideas—they’re actionable, brought to life through stories of individuals who’ve pivoted mid-career to pursue joy and fulfillment.

Why You Should Read It?

Deepak doesn’t just ask us to “work” to our potential; he invites us to play. And when we play, we tap into creativity, passion, and joy.

The book isn’t a monologue—it’s interactive. QR codes link you to expert voices, and stories from diverse professionals inspire you to rethink your own possibilities.

If you’ve ever found yourself wondering what’s next, Play to Potential is a toolkit for reinvention.

postsData.content:
Emotional intelligence isn’t what you say.

It’s how you make people feel.

The emotionally intelligent people don’t force their presence.

They earn respect through subtle but powerful actions.

They know how to:
 Stay calm in tense situations.
 Read between the lines in conversations.
 Make others feel seen and valued—without saying much.

 Here are 10 ways to show emotional intelligence (without saying a word):

1️⃣ Offer a reassuring nod during tense conversations.
→ Acknowledges the other person’s emotions without interrupting.

2️⃣ Maintain an even pace in stressful situations.
→ Reassures those around you .

3️⃣ Smile gently when someone shares their vulnerability.
→ Creates a safe space for others to open up.

4️⃣ Respect silence when emotions are high.
→ Demonstrates patience and self-control.

5️⃣ Step aside to give someone space.
→ Recognizing when others are overwhelmed is a sign of emotional awareness.

6️⃣ Make deliberate, slow gestures during conflict.
→ Controlled movements convey calmness

7️⃣ Tilt your head slightly when listening.
→ Communicates genuine curiosity and attentiveness.

8️⃣ Subtly mirror someone’s body language.
→ Builds trust and rapport.

9️⃣ Place hand over heart when receiving heartfelt words.
→ Shows sincere appreciation

 Stay physically grounded in difficult moments.
→ Signals resilience, even when emotions run high.


Emotional intelligence isn’t always about speaking.
It’s about:
• Observing,
• Understanding,
• Responding thoughtfully.

These small, silent actions can leave a big impact, strengthening relationships and building trust.

Which of these actions do you think is the most powerful? Let me know in the comments ⬇️


️ REPOST, share with others to help them?

+ Followfor daily actionable tips on well being and growth.

postsData.name:
Shubhankar Nalawade
Shubhankar Nalawade
postsData.content:
3 Years of Running SocialPlug Media – 10 Lessons I Wish I Knew Earlier…
.
.
.
Three years ago, I took a leap of faith and started SocialPlug Media.

No roadmap. No guarantees. Just a vision and relentless execution.

Fast forward to today we’ve helped 50+ brands grow, generated results and built something real. But the journey? Far from smooth.

I’ve made mistakes, faced setbacks and learned these powerful lessons every entrepreneur should know.

If you're running (or planning to start) a business, read this.

1. Clients Don’t Pay for Hard Work - They Pay for Results

I used to think "the harder I work, the more I'll earn." Wrong.

- Focus on impact, not effort. - Charge for value, not time.

2. Sales > Skills (If You Want to Survive)

- Learn how to pitch. - Master client psychology. - Don’t fear rejection - it’s part of the game.

3. Not Every Client is a Good Client

Saying NO to the wrong clients creates space for the right ones.

4. Building a Personal Brand = Inbound Leads on Auto-Pilot

In the first 2 years, I chased clients. Now, clients come to me.
Why? Personal branding.

- Post valuable content. - Share your wins & failures. - Be seen as an expert, not just another agency owner.

5. Systems & Processes > Hustle & Chaos

Hustling 24/7 is not a strategy.

Build repeatable processes so things run smoothly, even when you're not around.

6. Your First Hire Will Change Everything

Trying to do everything alone is the fastest way to burnout.
- Delegate early. - Hire for execution, so you can focus on growth.

7. Raising Prices Will Scare You, But It’s Necessary

I used to undervalue my services. Then, I doubled my prices and clients STILL said yes.

Higher prices = Higher quality clients.

8. 80% of Problems Come From 20% of Clients

Some clients will bring more stress than revenue. Know when to fire a client - your peace is worth more.

9. The Market Rewards Those Who Stay in the Game

- Show up daily. - Adapt to trends. - Keep playing the game.

10. Money is Just a Tool - Your Health & Relationships Matter More

I’ve seen agency owners make big money but lose themselves.
What’s the point of success if you’re burnt out, unhealthy, or alone?

Balance is key. Work hard, but don’t forget to live.

If I could go back, I’d tell myself one thing - be patient, stay consistent and keep learning.

Now, I want to hear from you:
What’s one lesson you’ve learned in business?

postsData.content:
“Where do you see yourself in the next five years?”

A classic interview question that can make or break your impression.

And yet, most candidates either:

1. Give a generic answer: “I see myself growing with the company."

2. Sound overly ambitious: “I want to be in a leadership role."

3. Play it too safe: “I'm not sure, but I want to learn and grow."

Here’s the thing—recruiters aren’t looking for a *perfect* answer.

They’re assessing:

 Your clarity of goals – Do you have a vision for yourself?

 Your alignment with the company – Will they invest in you and lose you in a year?

 Your adaptability – Can you grow with changing business needs?

So, how do you craft a solid response?

 Tie it to the role:

“In the next five years, I see myself mastering financial analysis, taking on complex projects, and contributing to strategic decision-making within the company."

 Show progression, not entitlement:

“I want to deepen my expertise in FP&A, work on cross-functional initiatives, and eventually mentor junior analysts as I grow."

 Balance ambition with flexibility:

“While I have a strong interest in leadership, I believe growth is a continuous process.

My focus will be on developing skills that add value to both the company and my career."

A well-thought-out answer not only makes you stand out but also reassures the interviewer that you're invested in the role.

How do you usually answer this question? Would love to hear your take!

postsData.name:
Malkie Rimon
Malkie Rimon
postsData.content:
"Don't let your insecurities fool you into thinking you control the world."

My client was facing a pretty big dragon. She dropped this wisdom bomb on herself during a deep coaching session, and I had to pause (and have her repeat it) to let it sink into her conscious mind.

My client absorbed this idea, and suddenly, everything shifted.

Because here's what happens when we face dragons that seem too fierce to fight:
We try to control every variable

We overthink every scenario

We exhaust ourselves preparing for every possible outcome

And in doing so, something strange happens: we end up frozen, as if the dragon has cast its own spell of paralysis.

Our need for control becomes the very thing controlling us.

Sometimes what looks like thorough preparation is actually our insecurities trying to control an uncontrollable world. We think if we worry enough, plan enough, stress enough, we can guarantee victory.
But dragons aren't meant to be controlled. They're meant to be faced.

The real breakthrough comes when we realize that our job isn't to control the dragon, it's to show up and face it. Imperfectly. Bravely. One step at a time. Just like my client did.

Sometimes the most powerful thing we can do is break free from the spell of perfect control and trust in our ability to handle whatever flames come our way.

 What dragon feels less fierce when you stop trying to control every aspect of it? Share your story below, let's break some spells together!

comments.commentText:
For the sake of transparency, I'm going to share that I fell into this trap today, myself. 
For a few hours this morning it looked like my daughter would need to go back to the hospital, and get that major intervention. 

I thought I was preparing to deal with the crisis. In reality I was spinning my wheels.

And I didn't even realize it until she called me to tell me that the pain went away again (if it goes away, it's not the problem we are concerned about).

Control is an illusion that stands in the way of results.

The dragon metaphor perfectly captures that inner battle we all face at some point. 

As for dragons, mine has often been the fear of failure. For the longest time, I thought if I planned enough and perfected everything, I could avoid it altogether. But in reality, that pursuit of perfection kept me from taking real action. Facing it meant accepting that missteps are part of the process—and trusting myself to adjust and grow along the way.

Saima Afzaal-Copywriter Me, too. And facing those dragons had the side effect of making me significantly less anxious. You'd think not facing the dragon makes the anxiety go away, but that's the paradox of the dragon.

postsData.commentAdded: Such a powerful reminder! Embracing imperfection in the face of our dragons truly paves the way for growth. Lets face them courageously!

postsData.content:
The content that could change everything? It’s already in your head.

When I started creating content on LinkedIn, I’d spend hours thinking:

• What should I post today?
• Is this idea good enough?
• What if it doesn’t get engagement?

The problem?

I was looking everywhere except the most obvious place - my own experiences.

Here’s how you can pull content ideas straight from your mind:

1: Ask yourself the right questions:
• What helped my customers the most?
• What mistakes have I learned from?
• What frustrations do my clients face?
• What skills can I showcase?

2: Pick one skill.
Let’s say it’s copywriting.

3: Break it down into simple topics:
• How to format text for easy reading
• Writing content that actually converts
• Mistakes I made when I started copywriting

4: Turn one topic into 3 content ideas:
• A personal story → “In 2023, my copy converted TWO clients.”
• A skill-based post → “How I write content that converts clients.”
• A case study → “How my client signed 3 deals with my content strategy.”

That’s just from ONE topic. Think about all the ideas you already have.

You don’t need Google.
You don’t need AI.
You just need to trust your own experiences.

So, what’s the ONE topic you’ve been overthinking?

𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐭𝐆𝐏𝐓𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝. Insights that I wanted to read for a while esp. for labor markets and enterprise use :)

analyzed **4 million** conversations from their free and pro Claude users and revealed some good insights here. They mapped queries to ONET tasks and then job roles, nice trick to get this done.

1. Adoption is task-specific – Used for 25% of tasks in 36% of occupations currently. Software development is maximum penetrated.

2. Augmentation > Automation – 57% of usage helps humans refine work, while 43% automates tasks.

3. Who’s using AI? – Peaks in mid-to-high wage jobs (software dev, data science), low in manual labor & highly regulated fields (e.g., restaurant workers, physicians).

4. Most common tasks? - Writing, critical thinking, programming.

Anthropic in general have popularity among developers - therefore it is common to see high usage in programming tasks and computing profession. It will be good to seeanalyzing this kind of data to see more labor market trends.

Ever had a plan that didn’t go the way you expected?

Welcome to entrepreneurship. 

Surprises, good or bad, are inevitable. But the most successful entrepreneurs don’t just react to surprises. They use them. That’s the
in action.

Instead of seeing the unexpected as a setback, what if we saw it as raw material? A resource? A hidden opportunity?

Rigid business plans often miss this. We get so focused on executing “the plan” that we forget to embrace what’s unfolding in real time.

The truth is, some of the most valuable parts of a business don’t show up until you start. The best entrepreneurs stay flexible, adjusting and innovating as new things come their way.

Surprises will happen. We can’t control them. But we can control how we respond.

What if instead of fighting the unexpected, we leaned into it?
What if we built our businesses to use it?

That’s how innovation happens. That’s how resilience is built. That’s how lemonade gets made.

Commercial 4-Wheeler EVs are Moving Beyond Sustainability! 

The adoption of 4 wheeler electric commercial vehicles is accelerating for reasons beyond just sustainability.

As more EVs hit the road each month, we’re seeing a strong network effect—friends of existing EV users are inquiring at dealerships, and repeat purchases are on the rise.

What’s driving this rapid shift?

 Huge OPEX Savings – When daily usage exceeds 80 km, EV 4-wheelers become more profitable than their ICE counterparts.
 Driver Availability – The clutch-free, gearless driving experience and low Noise, Vibration, and Harshness (NVH) make EVs more attractive to drivers, fostering gender diversity in commercial driving.
 Reduced Maintenance & Theft Risks – No fuel pilferage, fewer moving parts, and real-time telematics mean lower admin costs and easier fleet management.
 Branding Advantage – Logistics players using EVs gain a competitive edge, appealing to eco-conscious clients while cutting costs.

 With low OPEX, easy maintenance, and seamless fleet operations, the last-mile intra-city market is shifting towards 4-wheeler EVs faster than expected—reshaping the industry and surprising stakeholders.

postsData.name:
Richard Smith
Richard Smith
postsData.content:
I’m an Account Executive and I will only take a meeting from an SDR if:

1. It’s with a really senior decision maker
2. They have a defined pain that I know we can solve
3. They have access to a budget that they have put aside to spend on products like ours
4. This sits in their top 3 priorities

If you dare put a meeting on for me that doesn’t tick those boxes, I’m kicking that back so you don’t get the credit for it.

I sometimes think this is the reason some companies have a pipeline issue.

Their SDRs book perfectly good meetings, but their AEs want ready baked opportunities.

So as a result, they don’t make the most of the meetings they do create.

My hot take?

An SDR should be booking meetings with the right personas (easily qualified), at the right accounts (easily qualified) who demonstrate a level of emotion/interest in the problem that you solve.

-Identifying pain?
-Building value?
-Justifying a business case for budget?
-Understanding where this sits on a priority list?
-Nurturing prospects who aren’t ’ready to buy’?

That’s for your Account Executives to do.

And if they are unable/unwilling to do it, then you need to coach them to be better sellers or find better AEs.

Reminder: a meeting from an SDR is ‘by design’ different to an inbound lead.

Only 3% of your market are active buyers.

You need to find the 30% that have a problem but aren’t active buyers.

Most of the time in sales you have to create demand, not serve demand.

comments.commentText: Too many AEs want a silver platter, not a sales process. SDRs open the door—great AEs turn curiosity into closed deals. Demand isn’t found, it’s created.
Neil Sarkar 100% Neil. The best AEs can turn 'this has piqued my interest' into 'closed won'

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Targeting the right personas and understanding their priorities are key to maximizing outreach effectiveness. Lets create demand!

postsData.content:
The block feature on LinkedIn is amazing. 

I only started using it recently. Long overdue.

I just don’t have the time or energy to be fighting with the trolls in the comments, regardless how amusing it can be at times.

They also don’t deserve the attention.

The troll trolls, they get blocked right away. They are just offensive and have their own agenda, they are not even smart enough to attempt to cover it up.

The leaders, HR, lawyers who want to come at me. I give them a chance. If they are not overly disrespectful, I will engage to reemphasize the point of the post.

I love and encourage respectful, well thought out, intelligent opposing views. Much better than the automated button pressing “agrees” or “insightful” lazy comments that many leave. I have had many incredible discussions in the comments just like this. Nothing better.

Unfortunately, respectful disagreement happens less than the disrespectful troll comments who only want to poke and prod and make you look bad. Where they get personal and question your credibility. I used to love to go back at them twice as hard. No more.

When they double down with more garbage it’s time to be done. If they show up on another post or start jumping on other’s comments with the same garbage, they are blocked and poof they’ve disappeared from the LinkedIn universe at least from my view.

The blocked button is amazing, powerful, and a huge time savings.

Bye bye trolls. You don’t deserve to see my content.

postsData.content:
The dark side of being ambitious that nobody talks about:

1000s of entrepreneurs fall victim to it ↴

I’ve always prided myself on being driven & hard-working.

BUT when that hard work starts paying off
I develop a bad tendency…

Here’s how it usually goes, can you spot it?

“My Linkedin is doing really well”
→ I should post MORE

“This business offer is really popular”
→ I need to offer it more frequently

“I’m having such a productive day”
→ I can’t give up NOW

Secretly I’m getting myself into a dangerous cycle:

↳ Always needing to do MORE

Not gonna lie, It’s been a hard pill to swallow - but my constant drive to over-excel isn’t bold or brave:

 It's just a disguised form of instant gratification - that actually comes from a place of insecurity.

Because otherwise,

WHY is my current rate of growth not enough?

It’s because sometimes I don't trust myself enough to:

→ Let good work breathe
→ Give processes time to work
→ Accept that the 80/20 means exactly that

 At the end of the day it's called the 80/20 rule for a reason, not the 100/100 rule.

I’ll be taking some big steps in my content and business soon:

But I’m making sure to intentionally ‘replace’ and not just ‘add’ to my output - and TRUST that I’m doing the right thing.

So this week I challenge you to:

- Define the absolute most important things
- Kill everything else off your week’s to - do list
- Be surprised at how little your output actually changes

See how little actually changes :)

 What would happen if you trusted yourself more and hustled less?

comments.commentText:
The tricky thing about being in a career rut is that it's a gradual process. You don't notice the slow decline until you suddenly find yourself trapped.

The good news is that a career rut is not a life sentence, you have the power to pivot, grow, and step into new opportunities.

Here are some steps that I took that helped me which I know would help you too.

Identify the ROOT CAUSE: Ask yourself what exactly is making you feel stuck? Is it a toxic environment, misalignment with your goal or lack of growth?

Reassess your personal long term goals and vision: If it does not align with that of the company you work with, then you need to consider a change of career. If it does then that leads us to the next step.

Talk to your current employer about enriching your current role.

Consider learning a new skill or upskill: This would bring a new excitement and spark.

Expand your network: Engage with professionals in your industry by attending networking events.

Seek Professional Help If Needed: If stress, anxiety, or burnout is taking a toll, speak to a career coach, therapist, or mentor.

Don’t ignore signs of mental exhaustion—your well-being is just as important as your career.

It’s tough to feel stuck, but recognizing these signs is the first step to change. Taking time for yourself and exploring new opportunities can make all the difference. Keep pushing forward

Emails were piling up faster than we could respond. Customers were frustrated, sending follow-ups that only made the backlog worse. Some had been waiting for days. Others had given up and taken their complaints to social media, calling our support team slow and unresponsive.

Agents were scrambling, digging through endless email threads just to figure out what was missed. Tickets got lost. Duplicate requests kept coming in. It was a mess, and if we didn’t fix it fast, it was only going to get worse.

That’s when I put Freshdesk to the test and built a 𝗺𝗼𝗰𝗸 𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝘀𝗰𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵. No coding. No stress. Just a structured way to turn the chaos into a system that actually worked.

 𝗢𝗿𝗴𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗰𝘁𝘀: I set up customer profiles in Freshdesk, so every detail was in one place. No more searching through scattered emails and spreadsheets.

 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝘁 𝗮 𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗸𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺 : I created categories and priorities for tickets, ensuring urgent issues were handled first and nothing slipped through the cracks.

 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗰𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗲𝘀: I wrote pre-saved replies for common questions, so agents could respond faster while keeping responses clear and consistent.

 𝗦𝗲𝘁 𝘂𝗽 𝗮 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗯𝗮𝘀𝗲: I built a self-service portal where customers could find answers on their own, reducing the number of repeat inquiries.

 𝗔𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝘀: I set up Freshdesk to handle follow-ups, ticket assignments, and reminders automatically, so agents could focus on solving problems instead of juggling admin work.

What surprised me most? How simple it was to go from chaos to control.

postsData.content:
You can't bore people into buying. - David Ogilvy

$14M. 30 seconds. One missed opportunity.

OpenAI’s Super Bowl moment felt like waiting at an airport gate.

You know that feeling—scanning faces, heart racing, anticipating that perfect reunion... but instead of the embrace, you get an empty arrival hall.

The irony runs deep: A company revolutionizing creative
chose human production over their own groundbreaking
technology for advertising's biggest stage.

We witnessed pixelation, heard carefully crafted music, watched high-end production effects—all human-made—while their AI video generator sat on the sidelines.

Sam Altman's bold prediction: AI will drive all creative work within five years. The clock shows T-4.

Yet when 115 million viewers tuned in, OpenAI delivered... traditional production that scored 2.41/5, ranking among the Super Bowl's lowest-performing advertisements (Marketing Dive, 2025).

This wasn't just a missed opportunity. It was a glimpse behind the curtain.

The question isn't whether we're better off having seen it.

The real question: If the pioneers of AI creativity aren't showcasing their own technology on advertising's biggest stage—what does that tell us about the gap between the promise and the present reality?

I want to know what you think. Share your thoughts

postsData.name:
Kevin Miller
Kevin Miller
postsData.content:
This photo was taken over a decade ago, just before my wife boarded the private jet behind us for a week-long luxurious girls' trip to Turks and Caicos. Now, before you assume this is one of those entrepreneurial flexes to make you believe I've always been some uber-successful titan of business, it is very much not.


In fact, we were nearly broke and living in a vacuum with no purpose or fulfillment.

The trip was entirely funded by the owners of our company and included their wives. It seemed like an overtly generous gesture at the time, but in reality, it was one of many luxury carrots dangled in front of my unchecked lust for the world's perception of success.

These temptations were always accompanied by "If you work hard enough and sacrifice enough, you can live a life like this too, Kevin."

I did work hard and sacrificed more than I would like to admit. And I got big results, but little valid rewards. The even harsher reality was that it was all in pursuit of a perverted illusion of worth. I was living a life that did not represent my personal or professional values, and I was miserable.

I'll spare the details of how I was able to exit that high-speed train to destruction shortly thereafter, but it was definitely a significant turning point in my marriage, fatherhood, leadership, and career pursuits.

I thank God for peeling the scales from my eyes to reveal the fallacy of success before it got much, much worse.

I've had a bunch of chats with Henry Mittelman recently, and in them he's mentioned "MIT"s ...

What's an MIT?

It stands for "Most Important Thing", and it's an acronym that he uses with the clients in his accountability program.

MITs are key because it forces you to narrow your focus to just a few key items, instead of spreading your attention around to a bunch of things (like most people do)

It's like Jim Collins once said:

"If you have more than three priorities, you don't have any”

Henry is going to be expanding on this concept in the executive roundtable that he's doing next Tuesday.

It's called "Breaking Through The Growth Ceiling", and if you'd like to improve your focus on your key MITs you should be there.

If your business feels stuck, it’s not the market, your competition, or even your strategy… It’s YOU. 

Harsh? Maybe.
True? 100%.


Because here’s the deal—your business will never outgrow the way you think.

If your mindset is stuck in struggle mode, your business will be too.

The Mindset Shift? Growth Happens from the Inside Out!

 Stop obsessing over the finish line—enjoy the run. Success isn’t a pizza delivery; you can’t track it step by step.
Focus on the process, and results will show up when they’re ready.

 Turn problems into plot twists.
Every challenge is just your business saying, “Let’s make this interesting!”
Instead of freaking out, ask: “How can I make this work for me?”

 Get out of the day-to-day chaos.
If you’re busy putting out fires all day, who’s building the empire?
Step back, strategize, and stop trying to do everything yourself.

 Lead like a human, not a robot.
Spreadsheets and sales funnels are great, but if you can’t connect with people, your business will feel as exciting as a DMV waiting room.

Build trust, inspire your team, and watch everything grow.

At the end of the day, business growth isn’t about doing more—it’s about thinking differently.

postsData.content:
7 Uncomfortable Truths About Holding Grudges (That May Surprise You)



We've all been there – that lingering resentment that feels somehow justified. But what if I told you that holding onto grudges might hurt you more than the person who wronged you?

Research fromForgiveness Project reveals that people who hold grudges experience higher blood pressure, increased heart rate, and elevated cortisol levels when merely thinking about their grievances. Consider this:

1.) Your brain can't distinguish between past and present pain.
↳ When you replay that grudge, your body releases the same stress hormones as during the initial incident. According to neuroscience research published in, this repeated stress response can shrink your hippocampus – the brain region crucial for learning and memory.

2.) That "justice" you feel? It's an illusion.
↳ Studies atdemonstrate that revenge fantasies activate the same brain regions as drug addiction. You're not serving justice; you're feeding a costly psychological habit.

3.) Professional success suffers silently.
↳ Research from theshows that employees who hold grudges experience a 30% reduction in workplace collaboration efficiency and are 65% more likely to miss opportunities for advancement.

4.) Holding grudges restructures your personality.
↳ A groundbreaking longitudinal study from thefound that long-term grudge-holders became less open to new experiences and scored lower on emotional intelligence assessments over time.

5.) Your innovation capacity takes a hit.
↳ When grudges occupy mental real estate, your brain's executive function – responsible for creative problem-solving – becomes measurably impaired. This effect persists even when you're not actively thinking about the grievance.

6.) The "they deserve it" fallacy.
↳ Studies in cognitive psychology reveal that grudge-holders consistently overestimate both the impact of their resentment on others and the satisfaction they'll receive from maintaining it.

7.) Grudges feel like physical pain.
↳ People who hold grudges report the same levels of life dissatisfaction as those experiencing chronic pain. The psychological burden weighs as much as physical suffering.

The path forward?

Releasing a grudge isn't about forgetting or condoning. It's about choosing your neural real estate. As Maya Angelou wisely noted, "You can't forgive without loving. And I don't mean sentimentality. I mean understanding that someone is limited by their background and history."

Your mental real estate needs new management.

Coaching works; let's chat.

J.P. Singh

postsData.content:
B2B eCommerce Success: Beyond Software, Into the Real World

Over the years, I’ve come to realize that true B2B eCommerce success isn’t just about software implementation—it’s about deeply understanding how businesses operate in the real world. Technology is just one piece of the puzzle; the real magic happens when you connect it with the day-to-day realities of manufacturing, logistics, and wholesale distribution.

I learned this early in my career while working with one of the world’s largest polyester manufacturers in Indonesia. I spent time on the factory floor, watching how computers communicated with machinery. Being part of an Oracle implementation taught me a crucial lesson—if a truck gate pass wasn’t printed, shipments couldn’t leave the factory, no matter how perfectly the system was set up. That experience shaped the way I think about B2B operations.

Later, when I moved to the U.S., I took over day-to-day operations at a commercial printing company. Again, working on the ground reinforced my belief that technology should serve the business, not the other way around.
Just recently, I visited a B2B customer near Boston and spent time understanding their manufacturing process. Seeing firsthand how our Magento-powered eCommerce platform supports their operations was a great reminder of why I love this space.

To my fellow B2B eCommerce professionals, consultants, and solution providers—I encourage you to step beyond the software and spend time on a factory floor. Watch how products are made, how orders are fulfilled, and how real-world constraints affect the business. The best solutions come not just from technical expertise but from true business empathy.

How many of you have spent time on a factory floor or in a warehouse? What lessons did you take away from that experience? Let’s share and learn from each other.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Understanding the real-world processes is key to effective solutions. Its all about merging tech with business realities!

postsData.content:
Stop coming to my Dm with these questions 

Get on a Free 20 minutes clarity call with me instead 

Honestly, If I get a dollar for every time someone asks me these questions about marketing… I’d probably be on a yacht sipping fresh coconut juice. But here we are 

When I started marketing, I had the same questions too. And after working with startups, big brands and helping them meet their marketing targets, I’ve noticed a pattern, everyone asks the same questions. So, let’s clear them up once and for all:

1️⃣ Do I need a degree to be a great marketer?

No. What you need is SKILL. Experience beats theory every time. Take courses, learn, experiment and actually market something (even if it’s your own LinkedIn presence).

2️⃣ Which platform is best for marketing?

It depends on your audience. B2B? LinkedIn. Gen Z? TikTok. E-commerce? Instagram. But the best platform is the one where you can consistently provide value.

3️⃣ How do I get my first marketing client/job?

Show your work. If you can’t find opportunities, create them. Write case studies, document your learnings or even revamp a brand’s strategy for free to build credibility.

4️⃣ What’s the secret to going viral?

Consistency + Relatability + Timing. Going Viral is a mix of value-driven content, emotions and luck. But sustained growth? That’s from showing up daily.

5️⃣ How do I stand out in this crowded industry?

By being YOU. Your unique experiences, insights and voice are your competitive edge. Stop blending in, lean into what makes you different.

Marketing isn’t magic, it’s a mix of strategy, creativity and persistence. And the best way to learn it, is by doing it
